Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Signal processing for enabling high speed probe based nanoimaging

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
A key enabler of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology is the Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) that has opened up new realms, of interrogation and manipulation of matter at the atomic scale. It has resulted in breakthroughs in understanding sub-atomic molecular structure, protein folding dynamics and materials characterization. The potential impact of significantly faster AFM based imaging is immense, e.g., it will allow the study of dynamics of material at the nanoscale that was hitherto not accessible. The aim of this research is to study modern signal processing techniques that achieve gains in imaging speeds by an order of magnitude. The investigators will push the synergistic transfer of knowhow between the engineering and the AFM communities through student visits and specialized workshops. The findings will be integrated at appropriate levels into the undergraduate and graduate curriculum.

The main component of an AFM is a cantilever that deflects in response to forces at the pico-Newton scale. The focus of this research is the dynamic mode AFM operation, where the cantilever gently taps the sample being imaged; the mode of choice for imaging biological samples. Even though forces do form a good indicator of sample topography, the system memory and the nonlinearities of the AFM system dynamics preclude a direct mapping of the cantilever forces into a finer description of topography, especially at high imaging speeds. The investigators model the complex nanoscale interactions in a mathematically tractable manner that facilitates the development of maximum a posteriori (MAP) sequence detection of the sample features. Factor graph representations and the development of appropriate inference schemes will be studied. The algorithms will be implemented on FPGAs and tested exhaustively with experimental data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overall Description:  Recent progress in nanotechnology has made it possible to probe and manipulate matter at the nanometer and smaller scales. A key enabler of such advances is the atomic force microscope (AFM) which employs a small cantilever with a sharp tip at one end to probe. The operational principle is similar to that of a gramophone where a sharp tip is positioned relative to the media and the deflection of the tip provides a measure of the topography of the media. Given the ability of the AFM to interrogate matter at the nanometer scale it holds the possibility of achieving unparalleled density of information that can be recorded and read from the media. The project outcomes include methods for reading data from data storage media with high information density. Moreover, outcomes include a new method for measuring the fidelity and quality of the information that is read.

Intellectual Merit:  AFM based investigation of matter and data storage applications involve deciphering topography of surfaces with better than nanometer spatial resolution.  The main probe of the AFM is a sharp tip that deflects due to interaction with atoms on the media surface. In many scenarios where soft matter is involved, the cantilever is oscillated where the interaction with the media changes the nature of the probe’s oscillations. Often, in high bandwidth scenarios, the past interaction with the media interferes with and alters the current interaction with the media making it difficult to glean the information on the topography of the media from the measurements of the cantilever oscillations. Under projects outcome a real-time method was devised to accurately indicate the confidence on the fidelity of a black and white image of the media with respect to the actual topography. A key enabler is the introduction of systems concepts in deciphering the physics of the AFM probe based system. 

Another significant outcome obtained is the analysis of error rates when reading data from data storage devices. The key innovation was to employ techniques from communications and information theory area toward analysis of dynamics with Gauss-Markov noise.  

The project outcome also includes a new method that is considerably faster in reading data using the AFM probe based data storage platform. Here well characterized models of the probe and its interaction with media play a crucial role in enhancing fast detection of data.

Broader Impact:  Atomic force microscopy has become the standard for characterizing and testing of material. Thus the project outcome directly impacts the material discovery effort which continues revolutionizing science and technology. The outcomes provide new and novel methods for data storage applications and open up the probe based investigation area to tools from information and communications areas. The project has led to two graduate students trained in the interdisciplinary areas who have obtained PhD degrees related to the topics.
